newsitem.title: USA: $200mln Conn. steel plant targeted for 1999.
newsitem.headline: $200mln Conn. steel plant targeted for 1999.

text.p: A $200-million start-up stainless steel plant is expected to open in late 1999, officials said on Friday.
However, steel industry analysts were startled by the announcement and questioned whether the Williams Specialty Steel Inc plant would actually get off the ground.
"It is much too early to become concerned with the possible impact of this plant on the global stainless industry," said Michael Gambardella, analyst at J.P. Morgan Securities Inc.
He cited the proposed plant's relatively small size, uncertain demand, and unlikely location.
High-cost Connecticut has been losing manufacturing jobs for years, and New Haven has tried to reinvent itself as a center of high-tech and biomedical enterprise.
Connecticut Gov. John Rowland (R) announced the project on Thursday, and other officials gave more details on Friday.
When completed, the plant will be one of the most highly automated steel factories in the world, said Roy Breward, deputy director of the Connecticut Development Authority.
"The manufacturing will rely on efficiency and low cost," Breward told Reuters. "They have recognized that in Connecticut they can get both."

United Illuminating Co. will build an electrical substation at the 27-acre site and provide reduced power rates to the plant, services valued at about $5 million, said Anthony Uzzo, economic development specialist at United Illuminating.
Williams Specialty is the first venture into stainless steel manufacturing by Niagara Falls, N.Y. businessman James Harry Williams.
Williams' background is in the waste management business, and he is president of Integrated Waste Services Inc .
Some 3,000 workers will be hired to construct the 250,000 square foot plant, beginning in September, Breward said.
At full capacity, there will be 350 permanent blue-collar jobs paying $40,000 or more annually.
The plant will produce up to 500,000 tons annually of stainless steel, a more durable, but expensive, alternative to traditional carbon steel.
Some $70 million in loans will be provided by the state, the city of New Haven and United Illuminating, said Uzzo.
New Haven will issue $55 million in bonds to help finance the plant's construction.
That debt will be repaid in five years with real estate taxes from the plant. In return, the city gets jobs and an estimated $2 million more in annual tax revenue from the company.
Connecticut is providing $9.75 million in loans and another $1 million in grants for worker training.
Despite perceptions that nuts and bolts industries are dying, Connecticut has not given up on its manufacturing base, Uzzo said.

"It's a fallacy about manufacturing in Connecticut," he said. "We're seeing an evolution. There has been a net reduction in the labor force... but high-tech manufacturing jobs have been created in Connecticut."
"One reason the Williams company liked Connecticut is the (state's) emphasis on high-tech," he said.
But analysts still expressed surprise.

"Stainless steel scrap is not overly abundant (in Connecticut), guidelines regarding air quality are generally strict, and the logical consumers of stainless steel slabs are not located nearby," said Gambardella of J.P. Morgan.
"Optimality of location notwithstanding, it is uncertain that demand for stainless slabs warrants new stainless slab capacity," he said.
--Matthew Lewis, Hartford newsroom (860) 727-0224
